title: Tropical Storm Hone forms as it churns toward Hawaii , continues to strengthen
message:
Hone, the first named storm of the 2024 central Pacific hurricane season, formed after thunderstorms in the eastern Pacific merged and rapidly organized in recent days.
The storm was churning west-northwest at 14 mph, according to the Central Pacific Hurricane Center's 5 p.m.
The forecast cone of Tropical Storm Hone shows it sliding south of the Hawaiian islands over the next few days.
Tropical storm raises multiple concerns as track remains uncertainAccuWeather meteorologists said the potential impacts of Tropical Storm Hone will greatly depend on how close the system comes to the islands of Hawaii.
This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Tropical Storm Hone heads toward Hawaii, intensifies in Pacific

title: Haunting photo shows tourists caught by first tsunami wave of disaster that claimed more than 220 , 000 lives
message:
The devastating disaster claimed the lives of over 220,000 people, while injuring thousands more in what was the third largest earthquake since 1900.
It took several years to clear up the devastation left behind in affected places such as Indonesia, Sri Lanka, India and Thailand.
The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake hit a magnitude of 9.1.
Sri Lanka is 1,100 miles from Sumatra, and it took two hours for the tsunami to reach the South Asian island.
The overall fatality figure included approximately 9,000 foreign tourists that came from several other nations, making the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami and earthquake one of the worst natural disasters in history.

title: The Largest Tsunami Ever Recorded Only Claimed 2 Lives
message:
The Lituya Bay tsunami occurred on July 9, 1958, when an earthquake struck the Alaskan panhandle along the Fairweather fault line.
Luckily, there weren't many people in or around the bay at that time, and only three boats were hit by the world's largest recorded tsunami.

title: Storm Lilian : Weather warnings issued ahead of high winds and heavy rain
message:
Status Yellow weather warnings have been issued with Storm Lilian set to hit Ireland later this evening.
A Status Yellow rain warning will come into force at 10pm tonight in Clare, Galway, Roscommon, Longford, Louth, Meath, Offaly and Westmeath.
The forecaster said the heavy rain will bring the risk of localised flooding and difficult travelling conditions.
AdvertisementLater, a Status Yellow wind warning will come into force for Munster, Wexford, Wicklow, Carlow, Kilkenny, Laois, Kildare, Dublin.
It comes after the tail end of Hurricane Ernesto brought high winds and rain to many parts of Ireland overnight.

title: Live radar : Rain soaks South Florida – NBC 6 South Florida
message:
South Florida was dealing with scattered afternoon downpours on Thursday associated with a front nearby which will keep us in an unsettled pattern.
Thursday's rain triggered a flood advisory for portions of South Florida but it was later cancelled.
On Friday, rain chances will be slightly lower, and most of the activity will be inland.
Sign up for the NBC 6 Weather newsletter to get the latest forecast in your inbox.

title: Extreme weather hitting close to home for 1 / 3 of Canadians : poll
message:
The results from a recent Leger poll suggest more than one in three Canadians have been touched directly by extreme weather such as forest fires, heat waves, floods or tornadoes.
When Leger asked the same question in June 2023, around one in four Canadians indicated they had been impacted by extreme weather.
The number of people touched by extreme weather jumped significantly in every province but Manitoba and Saskatchewan, which stayed the same at 21 per cent.
Almost half of those polled in Atlantic Canada say they have been touched by extreme weather, up from less than one-third a year ago.
Despite all that, people who took the survey were less likely to be concerned about climate change now than in 2023.

title: No tsunami threat following 4 . 7 earthquake on Hawaiʻi Island : Maui Now
message:
Preliminary magnitude 4.7 earthquake reported overnight on Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024 on Hawaiʻi Island.
PC: USGSA preliminary magnitude 4.7 earthquake was reported at 12:52 a.m. on Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024 about 9 miles south of Fern Forest on the South Flank of the Kīlauea Volcano on Hawaiʻi Island.
The Pacific Tsunami Warning Center issued a statement saying there was no tsunami expected, however some areas may have experienced shaking.
The quake was widely felt in Hilo, Keaʻau and Pāhoa on Hawaiʻi Island, according to the USGS “Did You Feel It?” website.
The USGS Hawaiian Volcano Observatory reports the earthquake had no apparent impact on either Maunaloa or Kīlauea volcanoes.

title: Are You Sure Your House Is Worth That Much ?
message:
Updated at 5:02 p.m. on August 22, 2024Across the United States, homeowner’s insurance is getting more expensive.
Many economists now think that, because home prices don’t yet reflect climate reality, a new housing bubble is growing.
A 2023 paper, for instance, found that U.S. residential properties are overvalued by $121 billion to $237 billion for current flood risks alone.
Unlike the housing bubble of the previous recession, this one won’t leave homes to gain back their value over time.
But all three analysts I spoke with wanted to see the U.S. government create a comprehensive tool for homebuyers to better assess the climate risks of buying a house in a particular area.

title: Japan : Robot Attempt To Get Nuclear Fuel Sample Of Damaged Fukushima Daiichi Reactor Suspended
message: InternationalJapan: Robot's Attempt To Get Nuclear Fuel Sample Of Damaged Fukushima Daiichi Reactor SuspendedThe work was stopped Thursday morning when workers noticed that five 1.5-meter (5-foot) pipes used to maneuver the robot were placed in the wrong order and could not be corrected within the time limit for their radiation exposure, the plant operator Tokyo Electric Power Company Holdings said.

title: Leftover sandbags : what should you do with them ?
message:
Leftover sandbags: What should you do with them?
One thing you can do is store the sandbags in a dry, covered area for up to a year so they can be used again if needed.
You also should not dump sandbags on the beach or into creeks, rivers, canals, ditches or roadway gutters.
You can also reach out to neighbors, community centers, local emergency agencies or public work departments to see if they might have a use for them.
If you believe your sandbags are contaminated, contact your local public works department to find out where and how you should dispose of them.

title: Posts falsely depict old Japan quake photos as aftermath of August 2024 jolt
message:
Posts falsely depict old Japan quake photos as aftermath of August 2024 joltSocial media users have shared a photo collage of damaged buildings and roads from previous earthquakes in Japan, falsely claiming the images show the impact of a 7.1-magnitude tremor that struck off the country's south in August 2024.
Screenshot of the false Facebook post, taken August 21, 2024The post racked up more than 680 shares.
Japan recently lifted a warning that a "megaquake" potentially causing colossal damage and loss of life could strike (archived link).
The caption of the January 7, 2024 post says the images were shot as the force inspected earthquake damage in Wajima city in Japan's Noto Peninsula.
AFP has previously fact-checked misinformation on the recent Japan earthquake here and here.

title: Met Office warns united kingdom households to  fasten doors and windows
message:
The Met Office has issued a weather warning, advising households to "securely fasten doors and windows" as the UK braces for high winds reaching up to 70mph.
A massive 490-mile-long weather front, the remnants of Hurricane Ernesto, has headed towards Britain after causing destruction in the US and Caribbean.
Now downgraded to a storm, Ernesto is predicted to still be powerful and is part of a series of stormy events forecasted by AccuWeather to impact the UK from Thursday (22 August) into the weekend, reports the Express.
(Image: WXCharts)The Met Office recommends staying indoors as much as possible during high winds and advises against walking or sheltering near buildings and trees if outside.
To prepare for the storms, the agency suggests: "Close and securely fasten doors and windows, particularly those on the windward side of the house, and especially large doors such as those on garages."

title: Hurricane tracker : Gilma strengthens into Category 3
message:
HONOLULU -Tropical Storm Hone formed in the central Pacific Ocean on Thursday on a forecast path that may cross near Hawaii's Big Island, while major Hurricane Gilma remained a Category 3 storm at sea.
Hone had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph) and was centered about 1,090 miles (1,760 kilometers) east-southeast of Honolulu, the Central Pacific Hurricane Center said in an 11 a.m. advisory.
Meanwhile, Hurricane Gilma remained a major hurricane with maximum sustained winds at 125 mph (205 kph).
Gilma was trailing behind Hone, located about 1,980 miles (3,185 kilometers) east of Hilo and moving west-northwest at 7 mph (11 kph).
Hurricane-force winds extended outward up to 35 miles (56 kilometers) from the center of Gilma and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 115 miles (185 kilometers), the National Hurricane Center in Miami said.

title: Salvation Army providing widespread relief to thousands in Tioga / Potter Counties
message:
As communities continue to clean up and rebuild, many agencies responded to the impacted areas to help, including the Salvation Army.
The Salvation Army announced on Wednesday thousands of meals were provided to residents, first responders, and state incident management team members in the two counties since teams arrived in the areas to lend aid.
The Salvation Army stated that 266 incidents of emotional and spiritual care have been supplied, such as a hug, an ear to listen to, a prayer, blankets, pillows, and other comfort items.
Westfield, PA recovering after Friday’s stormThe Salvation Army says it will leave food boxes and other supplies that will help the community as residents get back on their feet.
Some of the most needed items consist of trash cans, totes, fans, tarps, push brooms, toilet paper, paper towels, new towels, new bedsheets, gift cards, and rubber boots.

message:
MEXICO CITY, Mexico -Gilma strengthened into a Category 2 hurricane Wednesday afternoon in the eastern Pacific Ocean and was forecast to become a major hurricane as soon as Thursday.
Hurricane Gilma was located about 975 miles (1,570 kilometers) west-southwest of the southern tip of the Baja California peninsula of Mexico, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
The storm could become a Category 4 hurricane by Thursday afternoon, forecasters said.
Gilma had strengthened to tropical storm status on Sunday.

title: Fukushima Nuclear Fuel Debris Removal Work Halted
message:
(MENAFN- IANS) Tokyo, Aug 22 (IANS) Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO) on Thursday decided to halt preparatory work for the test retrieval of nuclear debris from one of the crippled reactors at the disaster-stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.
2 unit at the in Fukushima Prefecture on Thursday, but setup errors were discovered during preparations in the debris retrieval device, according to the utility, reports Xinhua news agency.
It is the first such attempt to take out fuel debris in 13 and a half years since the Fukushima nuclear plant was devastated by a massive earthquake and tsunami.
2 reactor as the first to start the fuel debris retrieval work as its reactor building was the only one not to suffer a hydrogen explosion.
An estimated 880 tons of fuel debris remain in the three reactors.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Forms In Atlantic : Here 5 - Day Projected Path
message:
The projected timing and track of the tropical rainstorm through Friday evening, Aug. 16, is shown in the image above, just released late Monday by the National Hurricane Center.
The rainstorm is "forecast to intensify and bring heavy rainfall, gusty winds, and storm surge to parts of the Lesser Antilles, Puerto Rico, and the Dominican Republic this week," according to a statement by AccuWeather.com.

title: 4 . 7 - magnitude earthquake rattles Hawaii Island amid busy week of seismic activity
message:
HONOLULU (HawaiiNewsNow) - A 4.7-magnitude earthquake struck Hawaii Island early Thursday morning, the U.S. Geological Survey said.
The quake happened at 12:52 a.m. south of Fern Forest, at a depth of four miles below sea level.
“Most earthquakes in this region are caused by abrupt motion of Kilauea volcano’s south flank, which moves to the southeast over the oceanic crust,” said the U.S. Geological Survey.
USGS’ “Did You Feel It?” page reported more than 300 responses within the first hour.
This comes amid a busy week of seismic activity in the area.

title: Scotland soggy summer continues as Storm Lilian brings more high winds and heavy rain
message:
Scotland is braced for more heavy rain and high winds with the arrival of the first named storm since spring.
Yellow weather warnings will be in force during the storm as two-and-a-half inches of rain could fall on ground which is already saturated.
The Argyllshire Gathering in Oban, Argyll, was hit with the tail end of Wednesday’s wind and rain yesterday, with two young dancers forced to wrap themselves in a blanket to keep warm.
The latest spell of miserable summer weather comes in a week when there have already been two yellow warnings for heavy rain.
There were two dramatic coastal rescues earlier in the week as a man had to be helped to safety by the coastguard after his yacht ran aground in high winds in the Outer Hebrides on Wednesday.

title: As the world burns : the art and science of responding to B . C . wildfires
message:
Wildfires impact our lives and our communities — what does science say about how they happen, and how to respond?
Every morning during the months-long fire season, Matt MacDonald, lead fire weather forecaster with the BC Wildfire Service, examines conditions with his team and hundreds of frontline firefighters.
We should know how fires are fought.”Why is it so challenging to fight wildfires in B.C.?
MacDonald, who worked as an Environment Canada meteorologist for 18 years before joining the BC Wildfire Service in 2020, said he’s witnessed underlying climatic conditions intensify over the past two decades.
This year, a 24-year-old firefighter with the Alberta Wildfire service died while responding to the Jasper fire.

title: Met Office confirms exact date Storm Lilian is set to hit united kingdom with 80mph winds
message:
Met Office confirms exact date Storm Lilian is set to hit UK with 80mph windsThe Met Office has confirmed Storm Lilian will hit the UK on Friday.
Picture: Met Office & AlamyBy Will ConroyThe Met Office has confirmed Storm Lilian - the 12th named storm of the season - will hit the UK on Friday with winds of up to 80mph in some parts of the country.
Picture: Met OfficeThe Met Office said: "An area of strong winds associated with Storm Lilian is expected to move east across northern England during Friday morning.
Picture: Met OfficeThe Met Office urged the public to protect property, to check for loose items outside their homes and check for travel delays before heading out.
Storm Lilian marks just the third year when a storm has been named in August since they started being named in 2015.

title: When will hurricane season roar back to life ?
message:
Weather When will hurricane season roar back to life?
Experts are still anticipating a hyperactive hurricane season, but the Atlantic basin is ominously quiet.
NOAA / NHCThe typical peak of hurricane season has arrived.
Historically speaking, about two-thirds of Atlantic hurricane activity occurs between Aug. 20 and Oct. 10.
pic.twitter.com/LMJJjUKOdm — Brian McNoldy (@BMcNoldy) August 20, 2024Philip Klotzbach, a researcher at Colorado State University, is anticipating near-normal Atlantic hurricane activity over the next two weeks.

title: Hawaiian Electric monitoring stormy weather forecast , urges customers to review emergency plans : Maui Now
message:
File PC: Kalani PrinceWith the forecast of possible stormy weather this weekend and its potential impact to Hawaiʻi, Hawaiian Electric advises its customers to review their emergency preparedness plans and be ready for possible outages.
Strong winds and flooding can damage utility equipment or blow trees and debris into power lines, which can lead to outages.
When the weather improves, power lines must be inspected, possibly involving aerial inspections using helicopters and drones, and any damage must be repaired before service can be restored.
The company urges customers to review family and business emergency plans, ensure they have supplies they need on hand, and keep close watch on the development of the storm.
If you plan to use a ladder while preparing your home for the storm, note the location of power lines before you begin.

title: Gone Missing
message:
To the Editor:Just last week Senator Chris Murphy was in Kenya talking about flooding/drought that has affected that area.
Chris has no intention of coming to the Newtown/Southbury area after a historic storm hits the state he is supposed to represent.
I called his DC office and they said possibly next week he will be here, which seems unacceptable to me.
Yet he found time to go to Kenya (“checking on our investments”) and I was told he is taking a week off in Chicago.
Typical politician, when you need them most they can’t be found but I’m sure he’ll be here looking for votes in the Labor Day Parade.

title: A robot attempt to get a sample of the melted nuclear fuel at Japan damaged reactor is suspended
message:
An attempt to use an extendable robot to remove a fragment of melted fuel from a wrecked reactor at Japan’s tsunami-hit nuclear plant has been suspended due to a technical issueA robot's attempt to get a sample of the melted fuel at Japan's damaged nuclear reactor is suspendedTOKYO -- An attempt to use an extendable robot to remove a fragment of melted fuel from a wrecked reactor at Japan’s tsunami-hit Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant was suspended Thursday due to a technical issue.

title: Hurricane Ernesto arrived much too early – an ominous sign
message:
| Alejandro Granadillo/APAfter unleashing widespread flooding and knocking out electricity for half of Puerto Rico, this season’s third hurricane, Ernesto, has turned north and is approaching Bermuda.
In an average Atlantic season, the third hurricane doesn’t spin up until September 7, so Ernesto has arrived way, way early.
All that makes Ernesto, now a Category 2 hurricane, an ominous sign of what’s still to come in the next few months — and what to expect as the planet rapidly warms.
In July, the nursery for Atlantic hurricanes was running 2.8 degrees Fahrenheit higher than the long-term average.
Because the ocean takes longer to heat up than the land, the peak of hurricane season isn’t until September.

title: Wildfire Pollution Promotes Asthma Hospitalizations
message:
Higher levels of air pollution from wildfires were associated with significant spikes in hospitalizations for asthma and a slight increase in hospitalizations for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in surrounding areas, based on data from approximately 80,000 individuals.
In the current study, Horne and colleagues expected to see increases in the risk for asthma and COPD during summer wildfire season.
"This includes evaluating what biomarkers in the blood are changed by air pollution such as inflammatory factors, determining whether some medications may block or reduce the adverse effects of air pollution, and examining whether masks or indoor air purifiers have a meaningful benefit in protecting health during short-term air pollution elevations," he said.
"These data underscore the increased risk of wildfire-related air pollution relative to 'traditional sources of air pollution from industrial and transportation sources," he added.
Although the adverse effects of exposure to wildfire smoke and inversion season pollution on asthma were not unexpected, the degree of the effect size of wildfire smoke relative to inversion season was surprising, Rabin told Medscape Medical News.

message:
According to provincial figures, 26 per cent of the province is experiencing the second-worst level of drought while another 13 per cent (Vancouver Island, Bulkley-Lakes, and Upper Fraser West) is at the worst level.
Emergency Management Minister Bowinn Ma provided an update on wildfire activity and drought conditions on Wednesday.
Another eight basins are experiencing Level 1 or Level 2 drought conditions, meaning adverse impacts are rare or unlikely, while 12 are at Level 3, meaning impacts are possible.
Drought continue fuel wildfire activityThe drought conditions also continue to be a major factor in this year's wildfire season.
She added that the province and BC Wildfire Service also took and implemented lessons from last year, which have helped them along.

title: Canadian wildfire smoke hits European skies after travelling 4 , 000 km
message:
As a result, hazy sunsets have been seen across Europe including Ireland.
CANADA'S WILDFIRES: Visit The Weather Network's wildfire hub to keep up with the latest on the active start to wildfire season across Canada.
It was reported that wildfire smoke from Canada has been trekking across the North Atlantic since Aug. 10, finally hitting Western Europe on Aug. 17.
The result, aside from the picturesque sunsets and moon rises, has been a vast increase in levels of particulate matter and aerosols such as smoke particles in Ireland, the United Kingdom, France and Scandinavia.
That amounts to just more than 80 megatonnes of total estimated emissions for Canada in August, approaching the 2023 tally in which the country experienced its highest carbon emissions for the month since 2003, CAMS added.

title: Flooded farmers  forgotten about  by government
message:
The Farm Recovery Fund was set up by the previous government to support farmers whose land had been damaged by flooding during Storm Babet and Storm Henk.
Some early claimants received payment in July but a second eligible group - thought to include several thousand farmers - is still waiting for financial support.
Henry Ward's farm at Shortferry near Lincoln was included in May's expanded support scheme.
He is angry that eight months on from the winter floods he has not received anything from the Farm Recovery Fund.
Following complaints from farmers, the scheme was expanded in May to include many more farms that had been hit by over-topping rivers and exceptionally heavy rainfall.

title: August Bank Hell ! Massive traffic jams and train disruption predicted for tomorrow and Saturday as Storm Lilian rolls in
message:
Parts of Britain could face a washout Bank Holiday weekend as Storm Lilian is set to roll in, bringing with it heavy rain showers and gusts of up to 80mph.
The Met Office has warned of travel disruption, flooding, power cuts and dangerous conditions near coastal areas over the course of the weekend.
Lilian is the 12th named storm of the season — the furthest the Met Office have got through the list since it was introduced — and the first since April.
Storms are named when they have the potential to cause disruption or damage which could result in an amber or red warning, the Met Office said.
She said: 'Anyone driving in areas impacted by Storm Lilian should try to avoid exposed coasts and higher routes where there's a greater chance of fallen branches and trees.

title: St . Martin News Network - EOC Meets to Debrief on the Passing of Tropical Storm Ernesto .
message:
PHILIPSBURG(DCOMM):--- The Emergency Operations Center (EOC) met at the Government Administration Building on Wednesday to debrief on the national response to the passing of Tropical Storm Ernesto, the fifth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.
Each Emergency Support Function (ESF), which makes up the essential core of the country’s national disaster system, was presented for the meeting gave a presentation.
Fire Chief/Disaster Coordinator Clive Richardson said that the passing of Tropical Storm Ernesto tested all areas and levels of emergency response.
Richardson said the passing of the storm allowed the individual ESFs to fine-tune their emergency response mechanisms in preparation for the next system.
The remaining storm names for the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season are Francine, Gordon, Helene, Isaac, Joyce, Kirk, Leslie, Milton, Nadine, Oscar, Patty, Rafael, Sara, Tony, Valerie, and William.

title: Ernesto showed we work best together
message:

title: Five earthquakes hit Kon Tum Kon Plong district on August 22
message:
Five earthquakes struck Kon Plong district in the Central Highlands province of Kon Tum on August 22, according to the Earthquake Information and Tsunami Warning Center under the Institute of Geophysics.
Illustrative photo (Photo: VNA)Hanoi (VNA) – Five earthquakes struck Kon Plong district in the Central Highlands province of Kon Tum on August 22, according to the Earthquake Information and Tsunami Warning Center under the Institute of Geophysics.
Previously, on the same day, four consecutive earthquakes of respective magnitudes of 2.5, 2.9, 3.0 and 4.4, with a focal depth of about 8.0-8.3 km, also hit the same district.
Earthquakes have occurred regularly in Kon Plong since 2021.
According to Director of the Institute of Geophysics Dr. Nguyen Xuan Anh, Kon Tum in general and Kon Plong in particular belongs to a small fault, which see earthquakes with magnitude not exceeding 5.0.

title: Gilma becomes a powerful Category 3 hurricane and is forecast to strengthen as it stays at sea
message:
Tropical Storm Hone forms in the central Pacific Ocean, Gilma still a Category 3 hurricane View PhotoHONOLULU (AP) — Tropical Storm Hone formed in the central Pacific Ocean on Thursday on a forecast path that may cross near Hawaii’s Big Island, while major Hurricane Gilma remained a Category 3 storm at sea.
Hone had maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 kph) and was centered about 1,090 miles (1,760 kilometers) east-southeast of Honolulu, the Central Pacific Hurricane Center said in an 11 a.m. advisory.
Meanwhile, Hurricane Gilma remained a major hurricane with maximum sustained winds at 125 mph (205 kph).
Gilma was trailing behind Hone, located about 1,980 miles (3,185 kilometers) east of Hilo and moving west-northwest at 7 mph (11 kph).
The system strengthened to tropical storm status on Sunday and has grown more powerful since then.

title: Warning as Storm Lilian set to bring heavy rain to Angus
message:
A 12-hour weather warning has been issued for parts of Angus with Storm Lilian set to bring heavy rain to the region.
The Met Office has issued a yellow warning from 9pm on Thursday until 9am on Friday.
According to the Met Office, the Angus coast between Montrose and Carnoustie may see up to 50mm of rain falling, which could lead to flooding.
The Met Office says public transport may also be affected and spray on the roads could lead to increased journey times.
Met Office chief meteorologist Jason Kelly said: “Within the warning area, 50mm of rain is possible over high ground, with 20-30mm falling quite widely.

title: Unkept ditches causing drainage issues in historic Ashleyville
message:
WEST ASHLEY, S.C. (WCBD) – Unkept ditches are leading to newfound flooding problems in the Ashleyville neighborhood, according to residents.
The overflowing water Higgins described came from a ditch on Main Street which she said has not been cleared out by the City of Charleston for 2-3 years now.
Neighbors said the same goes for another ditch on Brookfield Street.
She told News 2 the city has denied requests to clean the ditches.
“We would like them just to pay attention to that and clean the ditches out so that it would address the immediate problem until we can get the Ashleyville drainage project completed,” Higgins said.

title: Extreme climate change : NOAA reports new terminology to address
message:
Creating a new language for climate change: NOAA releases a report describing a new term, "super-marine heatwaves," which has never been used before.
Scientists now have a new term, “super-marine heatwaves,” which has never been used before to address rising sea surface temperatures.
With decades of data, NOAA released a chart highlighting the changes in sea surface temperature in waters worldwide.
The sea surface temperatures are collected from the uppermost layer of seawater, which typically means the top few meters, NOAA explains.
NOAAProviding new language for the record-breaking sea surface temperatures, NOAA describes how “strong marine heatwaves” contribute to the temperature increases.

title: As the world burns : the art and science of responding to B . C . wildfires
message:
Wildfires impact our lives and our communities — what does science say about how they happen, and how to respond?
Every morning during the months-long fire season, Matt MacDonald, lead fire weather forecaster with the BC Wildfire Service, examines conditions with his team and hundreds of frontline firefighters.
We should know how fires are fought.”Why is it so challenging to fight wildfires in B.C.?
MacDonald, who worked as an Environment Canada meteorologist for 18 years before joining the BC Wildfire Service in 2020, said he’s witnessed underlying climatic conditions intensify over the past two decades.

title: EU allocates €122 million for humanitarian aid in the Greater Horn of Africa - Ethiopia
message:
The EU has released an additional €122 million for humanitarian assistance in the Greater Horn of Africa, as the region continues to face the impact of conflicts and climate-related disasters such as drought and floods.
In particular, the funding will be dedicated to partners working in Ethiopia (€42 million), Somalia (€40 million) and South Sudan (€40 million).
The Greater Horn of Africa continues to face complex and widespread humanitarian crises, mainly driven by conflicts and natural shocks made worse by climate change.
Over 70 million people are in immediate need of humanitarian assistance.
This additional funding of €122 million will support the scale-up of life-saving assistance to people in Ethiopia, Somalia and South Sudan.

title: NCDOT : Dickinson Avenue intersection closes for upgrades , set to reopen in seven weeks
message:
As part of the ongoing Dickinson Avenue Project, an intersection in Greenville is set to close for a lengthy amount of time.
The NC Department of Transportation announced crews will be closing the intersection of Dickinson Avenue and Moye Boulevard/ Hooker Road starting Monday August 26.
While this area is closed, crews will be conducting upgrades to the waterline, drainage, sidewalk and roadway.
Drivers can access Hooker Road by using Memorial Drive and Arlington Boulevard.
Officials say the area is set to reopen to motorists and pedestrians in around seven weeks.
